Architecture of system objects
The data entered into the System is stored as a custom object model.
This System model describes the structure of objects, their properties, operators, and interactions with other objects.
Each object of the System has its own set of properties (attributes) that distinguishes objects from each other.
Destination
Objects allow to implement and develop the functionality of the System in automation projects.
Related concepts
Since the term
object
is too broad a concept, there is a clarifying classification in the System that relies on related concepts:
Attribute – a significant feature of an object;
Object type – complete set of characteristics;
Instance – a set of information about a specific entity;
Object registry – a store of information of the same type.
Objects architecture
Attribute
It can sometimes be reffered to as
Characteristic
and
Object property
.
The System allows a business analyst to modify the current attribute composition of the object type at any time.
When configuring each attribute, a business analyst must specify its default value, whether it is obligatory to fill it in and other options.
The
Attributes
article describes the process of configuring attributes in more detail.
Object type
May alternatively be referred to as
Class
or less frequently
Object prototype
.
The System architecture allows to develop new or use existing (predefined) object types.
The business analyst must always follow the type hierarchy in case it is appropriate to create a new object type.
When creating a new object type, the parent object type from which all the parent attributes will be inherited (adapted) must be selected.
The missing attributes can be individually added to the created object type.
The composition of object type attributes includes personalized and inherited attributes.
Address the article on
Creating New Object Types
for more information.
The System has a list of standard object types (
system classes
) which cannot be edited. For the list of predefined types, see the article on
System Classes
. A
primitive object
is a special object type, a structure designed to store a large amount of data and for integration. For more information, see the article on
primitive Objects
.
Object instance
A separate object of the corresponding type, which can be alternatively named
Object
.
Instance is created by the System when the object card is inserted and filled in with real data.
Instances of objects are the items that users create and modify when working in the System.
The composition of the Object instance attributes is determined by the specific Object type.
Object registry
Object registry is designed for accumulation and long-term storage of data on all instances of a certain Object type.
The information can be entered and added manually or through programmed input.
Object registry is required to perform statistical processing of Object instances.
For more information, see
Working with the object registry
.
Principles of working with objects
The business analyst performs direct actions with the elements of the structure, and users access the data through the visual of Objects.
The business analyst designs the necessary structure of the Object model, using predefined and creating new Object types.
At the same time, all the attributes of conceived information structure are configured.
The ability to work with Object instancies and Object registries is valuable for users interacting with the System. The appearance of objects containing user-entered data is pre-configured by the business analyst. A
visual
is responsible for the objects' appearance. It can contain different set of attributes, grouping elements and design. For more information about view settings, see the article
Visual
.
